Life, if torn apart by hasty, thoughtless actions, is destroyed and cannot be regained
Life is always cheap and replaceable
Life should be spent in tearing fabrics

Because she wanted to leave Okinawa

An unsportive wrestler who broke the rules

She ran away from the arena
She asked the referee to stop the match

questions.question: What is being described as dancing
in the poem

questions.question: Why does the poet compare the clothes to
in
questions.answer: The clothes are compared to restive horses because they leap and prance in the wind in a lively, restless manner like playful, fidgety horses.

questions.question: What does the phrase
suggest about the clothes?
questions.answer: The phrase suggests that the clothes are very white and light, fluttering in the wind like small, bright creatures of pure whiteness.

questions.question: What happens to the speaker’s handkerchief in
questions.answer: The handkerchief struggles free from the pegs, flies away in the wind like a bird and is lost, never to return to the speaker’s pocket.

questions.question: Why can
and
be called eye rhymes in the poem?
questions.answer: They are called eye rhymes because they look similar in spelling but are pronounced differently and do not actually rhyme when spoken.

questions.question: Who was Thiruvalluvar and what was his occupation?
questions.answer: Thiruvalluvar was a great Tamil Saint-poet whose teachings are in Thirukkural, and he worked as a textile weaver who made beautiful fabrics and saris.

questions.question: How did the young rich man and his friends usually spend their time?
questions.answer: They wasted most of their time roaming around with friends and making fun of other people instead of doing anything useful.

questions.question: Why did the young man decide to trouble Thiruvalluvar?
questions.answer: He decided to trouble Thiruvalluvar because he did not believe people’s praise that Thiruvalluvar never got angry and wanted to prove them wrong for fun.

questions.question: What was Thiruvalluvar’s reaction when the fabric was reduced to rags?
questions.answer: He remained calm, smiled for the first time and firmly said that the fabric had become worthless, so he would not name any price for it.

questions.question: Explain why Thiruvalluvar says that many people had
to make the fabric.
questions.answer: He explains that from the farmer who grew cotton and picked each boll to those who carded, spun, dyed and wove the threads, many people worked hard over a long period to create the fabric.

questions.question: What is meant by saying that the work of the people who made the fabric would have been
questions.answer: It means they would feel happy and satisfied that their hard work was appreciated when someone bought the fabric and wore it with joy.

questions.question: How does the story show the difference between money and real value?
questions.answer: The story shows that money can be offered again, but the love, labour and usefulness destroyed in tearing the fabric cannot be brought back by any amount of money.

questions.question: What change takes place in the young man at the end of
questions.answer: He feels truly ashamed of his arrogance and decides on the spot to give up his idleness and bad habits, becoming a better person.

questions.question: What is a wall magazine and who prepares it in the class?
questions.answer: A wall magazine is a regularly changed display on the classroom wall showing students’ writings and drawings, prepared and maintained by students themselves with teacher’s guidance.

questions.question: Name two types of material that can be put up on a class wall magazine.
questions.answer: Students can put up poems, stories, jokes, riddles, drawings, reports of school events and other creative pieces on the wall magazine.

questions.question: Why is it useful to have student editors for the wall magazine?
questions.answer: Student editors learn to collect, select and arrange material, share responsibility and give everyone a chance to contribute in an organised way.

questions.question: Why is the new volcanic island called
questions.answer: It is called Anak Krakatoa because
means
, and the island is like the child of the original Krakatoa volcano that exploded earlier.

questions.question: What happened to the island of Krakatoa in 1883, according to the lesson?
questions.answer: In 1883, Krakatoa exploded violently, causing huge waves and destruction and almost completely disappearing under the sea.

questions.question: How did Anak Krakatoa begin to form after the explosion?
questions.answer: After the explosion, volcanic material slowly built up from the sea-bed, and in time a new cone rose above the water to become Anak Krakatoa.

questions.question: What does the lesson
show about nature’s power and renewal?
questions.answer: It shows that nature can cause great destruction through volcanoes but can also gradually renew land and support new plant and animal life.

questions.question: What is the
in the poem
and why is it called that?
questions.answer: The silver house is the moon, called so because it looks like a shining silver house in the dark sky.

questions.question: How does the poet create a magical picture of the sky in
questions.answer: The poet imagines the moon as a silver house with tiny stars as its lamps, creating a fairy-tale picture of the night sky.

questions.question: What happens to the silver house when day dawns, as described in the poem?
questions.answer: When day dawns, the light of the sun hides the silver house from our sight, so it seems to disappear from the sky.

questions.question: Why can
be called a play on words?
questions.answer: It is a play on words because the title itself twists
and
, and the lesson uses humorous word tricks to show how ads can mislead.

questions.question: What is one important message that
gives about reading advertisements?
questions.answer: It teaches that customers should read advertisements carefully, not be fooled by clever wording and think for themselves before believing claims.

questions.question: How does the shopkeeper in
attract customers?
questions.answer: He puts up eye-catching notices with tricky phrases that sound attractive at first but actually need careful reading to understand their real meaning.

questions.question: What is the relationship between Yonamine and her father at the beginning of the story?
questions.answer: Her father loves her but is worried because her unusual strength and love of wrestling make it difficult to find a suitable husband for her.

questions.question: Why did some suitors hesitate to marry Yonamine?
questions.answer: They hesitated because they wanted wives who would only cook, wash and make tea, and were afraid of a strong wrestler wife who could defeat them.

questions.question: How is Bushi described when he first appears as Yonamine’s challenger?
questions.answer: He is tall and slim, stands firmly and unshakeably on his feet and has dark, piercing eyes that show he is fearless and straightforward.

questions.question: What does the phrase
tell you about the wrestling match between Yonamine and Bushi?
questions.answer: It shows that they both fought with full strength and skill, using all their best techniques in a serious, competitive match.

questions.question: At what moment did Bushi manage to defeat Yonamine in the match?
questions.answer: He took advantage of a brief pause when Yonamine hesitated for a moment and brought her down with a swift punch.

questions.question: Why did Bushi warn Yonamine not to travel at night?
questions.answer: He warned her because there were bandits about and he felt it was unsafe for a woman to go out alone after dark.

questions.question: What disguise did Bushi use to test Yonamine on the road?
questions.answer: He disguised himself as a bandit by wearing shabby clothes, smearing dark colour on his hands and covering his face with a scarf.

questions.question: What does Yonamine’s reaction to the bandit show about her character?
questions.answer: Her swift, calm and effective defence shows that she is brave, alert, skilful and able to protect herself without panic.

questions.question: Why does Yonamine untie the bandit the next day even though he had attacked her?
questions.answer: She unties him because he begs for forgiveness and promises not to repeat his behaviour, and she is kind-hearted despite his attack.

questions.question: How does Bushi’s statement
at the end of the story strengthen its message?
questions.answer: It shows that he has learnt to respect women’s strength and warns others never to underestimate women simply because of their gender.

questions.question: In
, why is the young man described as proud of his riches?
questions.answer: He is described so because even after spoiling the fabric, he confidently offers to pay eight coins, believing his wealth can solve everything.

questions.question: How does Thiruvalluvar use the example of fabric to explain the importance of thoughtful actions in life?
questions.answer: He points out that just as tearing the cloth destroys many people’s labour, hasty, thoughtless actions can destroy a life that cannot be stitched together again.

questions.question: What is meant by the word
in the context of the young man’s behaviour?
questions.answer: Idleness refers to his habit of wasting time roaming with friends and teasing others instead of using his time for useful work.

questions.question: How do the activities after
help students understand rhyming and eye rhymes?
questions.answer: They ask students to list rhyming words and separate pairs that look similar but sound different, making them notice the difference between written and spoken rhyme.

questions.question: Why does the textbook ask students to wash and hang their handkerchiefs after reading
questions.answer: It encourages students to observe real clothes fluttering in the wind so they can connect the poem’s images with actual movements.

questions.question: What are students asked to do with positive and negative words in
questions.answer: They are asked to classify given words like great, beautiful, arrogant and worthless into positive and negative groups to understand their connotations.

questions.question: How does the lesson
promote cooperation among classmates?
questions.answer: It suggests planning together, sharing responsibilities like writing, collecting and arranging material and working as a team to keep the magazine lively.

questions.question: Why does the lesson
attract the interest of science-loving students?
questions.answer: It describes real volcanic activity, island formation and ecological changes, linking language learning with scientific curiosity about the earth.

questions.question: What feelings about nature can students develop by reading about Anak Krakatoa?
questions.answer: They can develop respect for nature’s power, interest in how land and life change over time and awareness of natural disasters.

questions.question: How does the poem
make the moon seem friendly to children?
questions.answer: By calling it a house and imagining it with features like lights, the poem turns the moon into a familiar, cosy image children can relate to.

questions.question: What skill does
help students practise apart from enjoying humour?
questions.answer: It helps them practise careful reading, understanding double meanings and thinking critically about what words really say.

questions.question: In what way is Yonamine’s story also about changing traditional ideas of marriage?
questions.answer: It shows that a woman can be both strong and loving and that a husband like Bushi can value a wife for her strength, not just for delicate work.

questions.question: How does Bushi show respect to Yonamine after realising she had tied him up?
questions.answer: He frankly admits that she has taught him an unforgettable lesson and accepts that he should never underestimate her or anyone else.

questions.question: What does the happy ending of
suggest about understanding between husband and wife?
questions.answer: It suggests that a happy marriage is based on mutual respect, shared laughter and recognising each other’s strengths.

questions.question: Why is the young man in
described as
questions.answer: He is taken aback because Thiruvalluvar remains calm and polite, quietly reducing the price instead of getting angry as he expected.

questions.question: How does the story of the fabric encourage respect for manual labour?
questions.answer: It explains in detail how many hands and how much effort are needed to create a simple cloth, teaching readers to respect those who work hard with their hands.

questions.question: What is a
in the context of cotton farming?
questions.answer: A boll is the pod of the cotton plant that contains the cotton fibres which farmers pick from the field.

questions.question: What does the lesson mean when it says that the threads were dyed
questions.answer: It means that the threads were coloured with care so that they took on even, beautiful colours without spoiling the material.

questions.question: Why is
presented as something the young man must give up?
questions.answer: Idleness is shown as harmful because it leads to foolish acts and wastes a person’s life instead of using time for meaningful work.

questions.question: How does the wall magazine activity help students improve their language skills?
questions.answer: By writing and reading others’ work for the wall magazine, students practise composing, editing and appreciating different kinds of English writing.

questions.question: What is one suggested way of decorating a wall magazine attractively?
questions.answer: Students can use colourful borders, neat headings, drawings and well-arranged columns to make the wall magazine attractive and easy to read.

questions.question: What kind of natural changes are described on Aank Krakatoa over years?
questions.answer: The lesson describes layers of ash and lava, new soil, growing plants and the arrival of birds and animals on the island.

questions.question: How does
connect geography and English learning?
questions.answer: It uses a real geographical example of a volcano and island formation to teach new words, descriptions and comprehension in English.

questions.question: What does the silver house poem teach about observing the sky?
questions.answer: It encourages children to look up, notice the moon’s changing appearance and imagine stories about what they see in the night sky.

questions.question: Why might shoppers in
be called
if they read carefully?
questions.answer: They are wise because they do not get tricked by attractive but misleading words and think clearly before believing what is written.

questions.question: What kind of excuses do villagers in
(linked in the unit) make to avoid sharing food?
questions.answer: They pretend there is no food left, pretend not to hear or speak properly and give clever excuses instead of admitting they do not want to share.

questions.question: How does the traveller in
finally get everyone to share food?
questions.answer: He claims to have a magic stone, starts boiling it in water and gradually encourages each villager to add vegetables, making a rich soup for all.

questions.question: How is Yonamine shown to combine strength with gentleness in the story?
questions.answer: She is strong enough to defeat wrestlers and tie up a bandit, yet gentle and caring in looking after her household and forgiving her attacker.

questions.question: What stereotype about girls does the story
challenge?
questions.answer: It challenges the stereotype that girls must be delicate and cannot fight or be as strong and brave as men.

questions.question: Why does Bushi say he does not want a
girl as a wife?
questions.answer: He wants a partner who is strong and capable like Yonamine, rather than a wife who can only do light housework.

questions.question: Explain the phrase
questions.answer: It means Yonamine kept the house very clean, tidy and well-ordered, without any dirt or disorder.

questions.question: What quality in Yonamine impressed Bushi before he married her?
questions.answer: Her skill and courage in wrestling impressed him, as he admired her strength and straightforward nature.

questions.question: How does Voyage Two use stories and poems to talk about work and effort?
questions.answer: Voyage Two shows the hard work in weaving fabric, the effort of volcano-formed land, and the practice behind strength and creativity, teaching respect for labour and perseverance.

questions.question: In what way do the units on advertising and the wall magazine encourage critical thinking?
questions.answer: They ask students to examine words carefully, plan what to display and not accept every written claim without thinking about its meaning.

questions.question: How does the young man’s destruction of the fabric show the effect of carelessness?
questions.answer: His careless tearing wastes months of labour and beauty in a few moments, showing how thoughtless actions can quickly ruin valuable things.

questions.question: Why is Thiruvalluvar’s calmness important for the message of the story?
questions.answer: His calmness contrasts with the young man’s foolishness and helps the young man realise his mistake without feeling attacked or insulted.

questions.question: What is the effect of describing the clothes as
questions.answer: It makes readers imagine the clothes as living creatures with round fronts and empty backs, enhancing the personification in the poem.

questions.question: Why does the poet of
choose March as the time in the poem?
questions.answer: March is often windy and lively, so it suits the picture of clothes jumping and dancing on the line in a merry breeze.

questions.question: What do the textbook activities suggest students should do with comparisons like
questions.answer: Students should complete such comparisons, change them into comparative degree and find suitable real objects to match them.

questions.question: How can writing for the wall magazine improve a student’s confidence?
questions.answer: Seeing their own work displayed and appreciated by classmates can make students feel proud, encouraging them to write and express themselves more.

questions.question: What does the word
mean in the context of
in the poem?
questions.answer: Restive means restless and fidgety, unable to remain still, which suits the lively movement of clothes in the wind.

questions.question: Explain the term
as used in the process of making fabric.
questions.answer: Carded means the cotton was cleaned and combed to remove seeds and straighten the fibres before spinning.

questions.question: Why is spinning an important step in making cloth?
questions.answer: Spinning turns loose cotton fibres into long, smooth threads that can be woven into fabric on a loom.

questions.question: What is the main moral of
questions.answer: The main moral is to respect the hard work behind things and to avoid careless, thoughtless actions that destroy what cannot be replaced.

questions.question: How is humour used in
to teach a serious lesson?
questions.answer: The humorous notices make readers laugh, but they also show how language can mislead, reminding us to be careful and wise customers.

questions.question: What does Bushi mean when he says he will
questions.answer: He means that by defeating Yonamine fairly in wrestling, he hopes to win the right to marry her and also gain her respect.

questions.question: Why is Yonamine’s father
before Bushi appears?
questions.answer: He is in despair because many young men fear Yonamine’s strength and unusual interests, and he worries that no one will marry her.

questions.question: What qualities make Bushi and Yonamine a good match for each other?
questions.answer: Both are strong, courageous and straightforward, and both can respect each other’s strength while also sharing love and household responsibilities.

questions.question: How does the story
show that learning continues even after marriage?
questions.answer: Bushi learns not to underestimate anyone, especially his wife, and Yonamine learns about her husband’s concerns and kindness, showing that they both grow together.

questions.question: What connection can students make between the handkerchief in
and the fabric in Thiruvalluvar’s story?
questions.answer: Both objects are small cloth items that can be easily lost or ruined, reminding students that cloth and the work behind it should not be treated carelessly.

questions.question: How does Voyage Two encourage students to observe and think about everyday things?
questions.answer: It uses poems about clothes and the moon, stories about fabric and wrestling and tasks like wall magazines to show that ordinary things can teach important lessons.

questions.question: Why do you think Thiruvalluvar refused to accept the eight coins in the end?
questions.answer: He refused because he wanted the young man to understand that money cannot repair the damage done to something into which so much love and labour had gone.

questions.question: How do the adjectives
and
apply to the fabric at different points in the story?
questions.answer: The fabric is beautiful when whole and carefully woven, but becomes worthless rags after being torn repeatedly by the young man.

questions.question: What is the role of the March wind in
questions.answer: The March wind provides the energy that makes the clothes caper, prance, shiver and skip, bringing the scene to life.

questions.question: Why does the poet of
say that the clothes are
questions.answer: This shows how they puff out in the wind at the front but remain empty inside, like playful but hollow figures.

questions.question: What do the activities about comparisons in the unit teach students to do with adjectives?
questions.answer: They teach students to use positive, comparative and superlative forms and to choose suitable nouns for similes like

questions.question: How does the story
use action scenes to keep readers interested?
questions.answer: It includes exciting wrestling moves, a sudden road attack and a clever disguise, which make the story lively and engaging.

questions.question: Why is Bushi described as having
that look straight at his opponent?
questions.answer: This description shows his confidence, focus and honest, fearless nature as a warrior.

questions.question: What lesson about judging people does Voyage Two emphasise through its stories and poems?
questions.answer: It emphasises not judging by appearances or first impressions, but by understanding people’s work, effort, character and hidden strengths.

questions.question: How does
connect the value of objects with the value of time?
questions.answer: It shows that valuable objects often represent months of human time and effort, so to spoil them is also to waste precious time.

questions.question: What does the handkerchief episode in
suggest about our control over small possessions?
questions.answer: It suggests that small possessions like handkerchiefs can easily be lost through chance or nature, reminding us not to be overly attached to them.

questions.question: How do the poems and stories in Voyage Two help develop imagination?
questions.answer: They ask readers to see clothes as dancers, the moon as a house, volcanoes as growing children and adverts as puzzles, stretching the imagination.

questions.question: What common idea links the lessons about advertising and the wise stone traveller’s trick (from Voyage Three)?
questions.answer: Both show that clever use of words or ideas can influence people, so listeners must think carefully instead of blindly believing or refusing.

questions.question: Why can Voyage Two be considered useful for both language learning and value education?
questions.answer: It teaches vocabulary, grammar and creative writing while also conveying values like respect for work, not wasting things, critical thinking and not underestimating others.
